title: Malaysia: Citi Launches Pilot Training Initiative as Part of CITI-UPM Financial Empowerment for Mature Women Program
summary: Selangor - Citi and UPM are launching the training initiative for 800 mature women from the low income group, as part of the Citi-UPM Financial Empowerment for Mature Women Programme. The program will be carried out among members of UPM Woman's Association (PERMATA) and National Council of Women Organisation (NCWO).
tag-1: Malaysia: Citi Launches Pilot Training Initiative as Part of CITI-UPM Financial Empowerment for Mature Women Program
tag-3: Selangor – Citi and UPM are launching the training initiative for 800 mature women from the low income group, as part of the Citi-UPM Financial Empowerment for Mature Women Programme. The program will be carried out among members of UPM Woman's Association (PERMATA) and National Council of Women Organisation (NCWO).
tag-4: The training program aims to help women – aged between 40 and 60 years, who earn less than RM 3,000 per month – become financially independent and empowered in their old age. The curriculum will include developing savings, investment and retirement plans, as well as inculcating positive financial behaviors to help women living in towns, suburbs and surrounding areas within the Klang Valley, achieve their financial goals.
tag-5: "At Citi, we realize the importance of equipping communities with the necessary skills and knowledge so that they have the confidence to improve their decision making, build assets and become economically resilient. A financially competent society is more likely to contribute positively towards the financial and socio-economic development of a country," said Sanjeev Nanavati, Chief Executive Officer, Citibank Berhad.
tag-6: Growing opportunities in Malaysia to promote financial literacy has been Citi's singular vision for the many community and citizenship initiatives that it has organized over the last 10 years.
tag-7: Through the Citi Foundation, grants have been provided to develop strategic partnerships that have enabled local organizations to carry out valuable work in this area. In 2010, the Citi Foundation invested more than US$20 million in financial capability and asset-building programs as a financial inclusion strategy in the United States and internationally. The strategy is based on the belief that financially capable individuals must have both knowledge about what financial decisions are right for them and access to appropriate products and services in a timely manner that will help put their knowledge into action.
tag-8: UPM's Vice Chancellor, Prof. Datuk Dr. Mohd Fauzi Ramlan, said, "We started planning our training initiative in the third quarter of our program implementation. The time is right for us to teach financial capability and asset building, which is the focus area of the program. It is also the focus area to the 800 women identified for the program, which should help women become more adept at formulating their own savings, investments and retirement plans whilst adopting positive financial behaviors to realize their financial objectives."
tag-9: Prof. Dr. Datuk Mohd Fauzi spoke at the launch event, which was witnessed by Dato' Sri Hajah Rohani Haji Abdul Karim, the Minister of Women, Family and Community Development, Malaysia.
tag-10: Citibank started the CITI-UPM Financial Empowerment for Mature Women Program in 2012, alongside its other partner, the Tsao Foundation.
tag-11: Citi Foundation's grant for the seven pronged-program encompassed building UPM's staff capacity and for the National Council of Women Organisation (NCWO) leaders to deliver the program effectively to low income mature women; conduct awareness among participants from various stakeholder groups such as the government, NGOs, statutory bodies and the private sector, and adapting and developing a financial education curriculum.
tag-12: It also involved carrying out needs assessment, undertaking focus group discussions facilitated by UPM, raising public awareness in the media and identifying a pool of 60 trainers from partner organizations. A minimum of five Citibank volunteers will also participate as trainers.
tag-13: "We appreciate that financial capability does not stand alone nor can a financial service provider do it all – it will require effort, collaboration and coordination from a wide range of stakeholders. Working hand-in-hand with UPM is a positive step in the right direction as together we can empower a community of older women improve their financial decision-making, build assets and become economically resilient," added Sanjeev.
tag-14: Over the years, Citi has partnered with Era Consumer Malaysia for the My First Ringgit and Stretching Your Ringgit programs, the Malaysian Invention & Design Society (Minds) and the Ministry of Education for Agent Penny, a primary school management program. Other programs were the Citi Stock Challenge, Making Sense of Money and the Young Enterprise Program for secondary school students. Over 100,000 students in the country have benefited from these financial education programs.
tag-15: Citi also hosted with Bank Negara Malaysia in 2005, a Financial Education Summit in Kuala Lumpur on developing a roadmap for financial education initiatives in the country.

tag-18: The Citi Foundation The Citi Foundation is committed to the economic empowerment and financial inclusion of low- to moderate-income individuals and families in the communities where we work so that they can improve their standard of living. Globally, the Citi Foundation targets its strategic giving to priority focus areas: Microfinance, Enterprise Development, College Success, and Financial Capability and Asset Building. In the United States, the Citi Foundation also supports Neighborhood Revitalization programs.
tag-19: The Citi Foundation works with its partners in Microfinance, Enterprise Development, and Neighborhood Revitalization to support environmental programs and innovations. Additional information can be found at www.citifoundation.com.
tag-20: The Universiti Putra Malaysia Universiti Putra Malaysia (UPM) is recognised by the independent government assessments as one of Malaysia's leading research Universities. UPM started as a School of Agriculture in 1931. It was originally known as Universiti Pertanian Malaysia. The only one of its kind in Malaysia, it has moulded thousands of independent thinkers to become society leaders and entrepreneurs. Today, UPM is a multi-disciplinary, research-centred university offering a diverse range of high-quality, world-class programs. UPM have 16 faculties, 2 graduate schools, 9 institutes, and 14 centres. Both of UPM campuses (the main in Serdang, Selangor and a branch in Bintulu, Sarawak) provide a learning environment that is conducive and dynamic, surrounded by the splendour of nature and equipped with the amenities you would expect from a top university. As a premier institution of learning, widely recognized for leadership in research and innovation, UPM continues to strive for excellence. In order to motivate the entire university community towards achieving excellence, it ensures that all the members, both students and members of staff share responsibility of strictly adhering of the demands of the University's vision, mission and goals.
tag-21: The Institute of Gerontology Institute of Gerontology (IG) is a research institution on old age and ageing created with the cooperation of the Faculty of Human Ecology and Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences. It was established on 1st April 2002. Currently, the Institute has two laboratories to coordinate its research programs, training and outreach activities, namely the Social Gerontology Laboratory and the Medical Gerontology Laboratory. The research programs emphasize economic security and intergenerational relationships in old age to inform policy, programs as well as services for older persons. Sustaining and restoring functional capacity to maximize older person's participation and independence towards a better quality of life are also key objectives. It also focuses on proper design of living spaces and targeted assistive technology to improve elderly ability to cope with existing disabilities. Both national and international funding/grants, consultancy opportunities as well as expert collaborations (e.g. WHO, UNFPA, UNESCO, UN-INIA, MOSTI, MOHE, MWFCD, DSWM, EPF, Citibank Foundation, Fonterra Brands) have been instrumental in the development of research capacity at the Institute of Gerontology (IG).
